items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  8.03
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Dale Scott, Financial Advisor, from Dale Scott and Company
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion of 2014 General Obligation Refunding Bond Sale and Summary of 2002 Measure G General Obligation Bond Program  
			 
In 2002, District voters approved Measure G, authorizing the issuance of $298 million in general obligation bonds for school facility projects.  From 2002 through 2008, the bonds were issued in eight separate series. Each series was sold with optional call provisions, allowing the bonds to be refunded should interest rates decline in the future.  The first five series have previously been refunded, providing a reduction in debt service of $14,537,637.73.  On April 17, 2014, the Board approved Resolution #2013/14-22, authorizing the issuance and sale of the 2014 General Obligation Refunding Bonds of the District for the purpose of refunding the sixth series of general obligation bonds, consisting of the Series F Bonds.  The Series F Bonds were originally issued in 2006 and are subject to redemption on August 1, 2014.  The General Obligation Refunding Bonds were successfully sold via a limited competitive bid on June 4, 2014, and provided a reduction in debt service of $7,561,803.31, bringing the total taxpayer savings from issuing refunding bonds under Measure G to $22,099,441.04.    
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
The Refunding Bonds are payable from ad valorem property taxes levied on taxpayers in the District.  Under California law, the Refunding Bonds can only be issued if there are debt service savings, which result from the refunding, so the taxpayers are assured that property taxes will be reduced as a result of the refunding.  The sale of the 2014 General Obligation Refunding Bonds resulted in a total savings of $7,561,803.31 to taxpayers.
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
The Refunding Bonds are payable from ad valorem property taxes levied on taxpayers in the District.  Neither the general fund nor any other funds of the District are pledged to the payment of debt service on the Refunding Bonds.
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  09.01
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public hearing at Approximately 6:30 p.m. for Resolution #2014-2015-03 Regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional  Materials per Education Code 60119
	 
BACKGROUND
Education Code Section 60119 requires that local Board of Education hold a public hearing and declare by resolution whether or not all students have access to sufficient instructional materials consistent with the State curricular frameworks and standards.  If the Governing Board finds an insufficiency, it must make known to the public the reasons for the insufficiency and take action to ensure that the situation is remedied within eight weeks from the start of school.  This public hearing is intended to comply with the regulation.
	 
Please be advised that the present California State per pupil allocation for the purchase of instructional materials is sufficient to provide each student with instructional support materials for each class for school year 2014-2015.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The Administration recommends that the Governing Board determine a finding of sufficiency in instructional materials and supplies as specified in Resolution #2014-2015-03 and hold a public hearing with due diligence on September 18, 2014, as required by the Education Code Section 60119.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  09.02
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2014-2015-03 regarding the Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials - Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
	 
BACKGROUND
In 2000, a class action lawsuit was filed claiming that some public schools were failing to provide students with equal access to instructional materials, safe and decent school facilities, and qualified teachers.  In 2004, the case was settled and required school districts to ensure that all students had access to the approved instructional supplies (textbooks). Governing Boards are required to hold a public hearing 
For ESUHSD, the school that are visited are Andrew Hill, James Lick, Mt. Pleasant, Oak Grove, W.C.Overfelt, and Yerba Buena. The Santa Clara County has certified that each of the six schools have met the "Sufficiency of Textbooks" requirement.  The certification for the schools that are not visited is done by the principal.  Each principal, for the non-visited schools submit a signed "Certification of Textbook Sufficiency". 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2014-2015-03 as proposed.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:35 p.m. for Resolution #2014/2015-04 Regarding the GANN Spending Limit
			 
			 
In accordance with the California Education Code, a public hearing is to be held prior to the adoption of Resolution #2014/2015-04 regarding the GANN Spending Limit. 
			 
The GANN amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the amendment must calculate their appropriations limit for the coming year.

Not Applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
					 
Item:  9.04
									 
TO:
									 
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
								 
								 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-04 Establishing Appropriations GANN Spending Limit  
					 
					 
The Gann amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the amendment must calculate their appropriations limit for the coming year.  There is no direct relationship between the figures, which appear in the calculations of the GANN limitation and other 2014/2015 budget data since the calculation deals exclusively with proceeds of taxes. 
					 
The attached resolution is being presented for adoption.
					 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
					 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
					 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution #2014/2015-04 establishing appropriations for the GANN Spending Limit.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent, and Rogelio Ruiz, Legal Counsel
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion/Receive First Reading of Amended Board ByLaw 9270 Conflict of interest; Revolving Door Policy and 9270 Appendix A Designated Positions/Disclosure Categories
	 
The Government Code and the Rules and Regulations adopted by the Fair Political Practices Commission require the District to designate positions which are required to submit disclosures of financial interests, and to update the titles of positions when new positions are created, when position titles are changed, or when positions or position duties are revised or modified to fall within the disclosure categories.  The change reflected in the attached draft proposed revised Board ByLaw 9270 and accompanying Appendix includes language that is in compliance with legal statutes and clarifies new positions to be included within the category of positions required to submit disclosures.  The District is required to submit the proposed approved changes to the Santa Clara County Counsel.
	 
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board receive the first reading of Board ByLaw 9270 Conflict of Interest; Revolving Door Policy and accompanying 9270 Appendix A Designated Positions/Disclosure Categories.

Item:  11.04
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Van T. L, Board Vice President, Frank Biehl, Board Member,  and Joshua Barrouse, CBOC Chairperson for Bond Measures G, E and I
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Appointment of Members to Serve on Measures G, E and I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee
	 
	 
As a result of the Board's discussion and motion of August 21, 2014, the applications of persons who were not selected to serve on the Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee for Measures G, E, and I were reviewed by Board Vice President Le, Board Member Biehl and CBOC Chairperson Barrouse.  Based on their review, they are recommending the following applicants to serve on the 2014-2015 Measures G, E, and I Citizens Bond Oversight Committee.  A copy of their application is attached for the Board's review.
	 
Selection #1:  Dr. Barry Schimmel (new member) - Member of the Community At-Large
Selection #2:  Vince Tran (returning member) - Member of the Community At-Large
	 
If approved, this will bring the CBOC Committee to a 13-member Committee.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
	 
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Consider Request by Board Clerk Magdalena Carrasco 
for an Excused Absence from the September 18, 2014, Board Meeting (Education Code Section 35120)
	 
	 
Board Clerk Magdalena Carrasco will be absent from the September 18, 2014, Board Meeting.  She will be in New York meeting with elected officials and business representatives and attending meetings and events relating to jobs creation and business and economic development.  She is unable to return to San Jose in time for the September 18 meeting, is not able to timely meet the agenda posting requirements in New York per the Brown Act, and would be unable to participate telephonically because of the schedule.  As a result, she will not be participating in the September 18 meeting.  
	 
Per Education Code section 35120(c), a Board Member who is absent from a meeting may receive his/her monthly stipend if the Board adopts a resolution finding that the Board member was performing services outside the meeting for the district, or he or she was absent due to illness or was on jury duty, or the absence was due to a hardship deemed acceptable by the Board.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$441 Board Monthly Stipend
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The Board consider Board Clerk Carrasco’s request that her absence is due to a hardship and that the Board excuse her absence from the September 18, 2014, Board Meeting on that basis.

Item:  13.01
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action to Accept the Unaudited Actual Financial Report for Fiscal Year 2013/2014
			 
Attached for your review is a copy of the 2013-14 Unaudited Actual Financial Report.  The report provides a detailed summary of the District’s fiscal status as of June 30, 2014.  Your approval is required to certify the 2013-14 unaudited actual financial reports as required by Education Code 42100. In addition, your approval will establish appropriations to account for differences between the estimated year-end balances and the unaudited year-end balances as required by Education code 42600 prior to submission to the County Office of Education and to the State.  The formal due date to the County Office is September 15, 2014.   
			 
INCLUDED IN YOUR PACKET:
A SACS binder detailing General Fund revenue and expenses for FY 2013-14 estimated actual vs. 2013-14 unaudited actual.  Also included are detailed summary information highlighting the same type of information for each fund including special revenue funds, capital project funds, and proprietary funds.  All summary worksheets prepared reflect the information required by the state for Unaudited Actual which are shown on the SACS forms.  
A Powerpoint presentation highlighting the 2013-14 Unaudited Actual Financial Report.
			 
ESTIMATED ACTUALS vs. UNAUDITED ACTUALS
Each year districts are required to include an estimate of the ending fund balance for each fund with the Budget Adoption process.  It was estimated when the budget was adopted that the general fund ending fund balance would be $41,152,960.00 and the Unaudited Actual for the General Fund totals $45,557,035.00.  The variance between the estimated actual vs. unaudited actual represents an increase of $4,404,075.00 to the 2013-14 Ending Fund Balance which has been brought forward into the 2014-15 Budget year as an increase to the Beginning Fund Balance for the General Fund.
			 
Board action is requested to approve and accept the 2013-14 Unaudited Actual Financial Reports as presented with permission to proceed with any additional final year-end adjustments that may be necessary. 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and accept the Unaudited Actual for 2013/2014 fiscal year report as presented with permission to proceed with any additional final year-end adjustments that may be necessary.

Pursuant to State mandate, the Governing Board must approve provisional internship permit requests allowing the district to employ and assign teacher(s) or administrator(s) who do not hold appropriate credential authorization.
	 
The Provisional Internship Permit (PIP) was created in response to the phasing out of emergency permits and became effective on July 1, 2006.  It allows an employing agency to hire an individual who has not yet met the subject matter competence requirement needed to enter an internship program.
	 
The district is requesting approval of the following provisional internship permit request for the 2014-2015 school year.

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Summer Short-Term Staffing Outcome
	 
On April 17, 2014, the Board adopted Resolution #2013/2014-23 to hire short-term non-certificated summer staff.  Over the summer, 29 short term employees were hired to perform maintenance, repairs and grounds related work, computer recycling and updating fixed asset data, all of which had become backlogged due to significant budget cuts that reduced staffing levels.  This summer work initiative used Restricted Maintenance and General Funds totaling $151,765.77.
	 
The work that was completed enhanced the aesthetics, cleanliness, safety, security and operational functionality of the school campuses.  Performing the work over the summer months provided ease of access to school site facilities.  Staff in the areas of Facilities, Warehouse and Information Technology operations will present “what got done” as a result of this summer staffing initiative.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  15.04
			 
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, André Bell, Assistant Director of Capital Accounting and Purchasing, Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Award a Site and Facilities Lease Agreements for Independence High School Performing Arts Center – Building F Lease Leaseback Project with McCarthy Building Companies (Project No. E-065-003)
			 
On May 15, 2014, ESUHSD Board of Trustees approved the award of the Pre-Construction Agreement to McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. (McCarthy), to be the Lease Leaseback developer for the IHS Performing Art Center Bldg. F (Item 15.3, Attachment A).
			 
Upon approval of the Preconstruction Agreement, McCarthy immediately commenced implementing components of their Agreement including reviewing the Project Plans and Specifications prepared by Cody Anderson Architects (CAW) for constructability issues, technical review, value engineering, and obtained pricing from subcontractors and suppliers to generate a guaranteed maximum price (GMP).
			 
As part of the thorough constructability and technical review of the plans and specifications, McCarthy provided information for potential conflicts in the plans and specifications that could lead to requests for information and potential change orders during the course of construction.  Van Pelt Construction Services (VPCS), the District’s Construction Manager, coordinated multiple meetings with McCarthy and CAW to review and address McCarty’s comments. CAW incorporated relevant comments into the final backcheck set of plans and specifications and are approved by Division of the State Architect (DSA).
			 
During the review of the plans and specifications, McCarthy identified multiple value engineering or values assessment (VA) options to address insure project costs remain within project budget. Each of these options were evaluated by the District’s Facilities staff, VPCS and CAW.  McCarthy incorporated the accepted VA options in the recommended GMP. 
			 
After commencement of construction, McCarthy may present additional VA options.  If these VA options are accepted by the District’s Facilities staff, these savings will be added to Contractor’s Contingency.
			 
To develop the final GMP, McCarthy divided the plans and specifications to thirty-eight work categories (WC) or subcontractor trade areas.  McCarthy solicited multiple subcontractors to provide bids for each WC, including subcontractors from the District’s approved list of subcontractors.  McCarthy interviewed the two lowest bid subcontractors for each WC to insure that their bids contained the full scope and met the experience and qualification criteria required by the contract documents.  VPCS attended several of these subcontractor interview sessions.  McCarthy provided the entire subcontractor pricing data used to prepare the final GMP.
			 
Additionally in developing the final GMP, McCarthy prepared a detail list of assumptions and clarifications.  Each of these assumptions and clarifications were reviewed and accepted by the District’s Facilities staff, CAW and VPCS.  
			 
Through this process of reviewing of the plans and specification for constructability and technical review issues, generating VA options and preparing the list of assumptions and clarifications, McCarthy developed their list of Owner contingency items.  This list was reviewed and edited by the District’s Facilities staff, VPCS and CAW.  As agreed by McCarthy, the Owner’s Contingency can only be used for a limited list of unforeseen conditions. McCarthy’s accepts the majority of design risk and unforeseen conditions associated with design conflicts.  McCarthy’s final GMP reflects this acceptance of risk.
Fiscal Impact:
Measure E: $8,610,000
Measure I: $851,006
Not to Exceed the Total of: $9,461,006.00
			 
Funding Source:
General Obligation Bond Measures E and I
			 
			 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a Lease Leaseback Site and Facilities Lease Agreements with McCarthy Building Companies, Inc., for Independence High School Performing Arts Center – Building F Lease Leaseback project in an amount not to exceed $9,461,006.00.

PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Amended Expulsion Hearing Committee Personnel for 2014-2015
		 
		 
An amended list of certificated and/or administrative personnel from each school in the District, including District office personnel, from whom individuals will be selected to serve on the Expulsion Hearing Committee for the 2014-2015 school year is attached.  Each committee is comprised of three certificated members who are not associated with the student’s home school.  The committee panel, chaired by the Coordinator of Student Services and/or a designee, is a non-voting member.  The committee meets on an as-needed basis.
		 
The amended list is representative of our District’s ethnic population and includes new administrative appointments.

Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of August 2014, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment of Goods and Services adopted in May 2009.  The Policy states that, "The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting."  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval on issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the "transparency" of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.

SUBJECT:
Approve Amended Final Change Order #1 for the W.C. Overfelt High School New Security Cameras in Building C & E Project, E-040-006 (Angotti & Reilly, Inc.)
	 
On April 19, 2012, (Board item 16.05), the Board awarded a construction contract in the amount of $207,180 to Angotti & Reilly, Inc. (see Attachment A).
	 
The original Final Change Order was presented to the Board of Trustees on March 21, 2013.  However there was a calculation error and therefore this amended change order #1 is the corrected final change order to deduct the correct unused portion of the owner’s allowance from the final contract price and accept the credit due to the District from the contractor.

PREPARED BY:

SUBJECT:
Update on Summit Public Schools: Rainier Charter School Mini Campus Modernization at Mt. Pleasant High School
	 
On August 21, 2014 (Board Item 18.11), the Board ratified the Facilities Use Agreement that District administration had executed on June 12, 2014, for classrooms, administrative offices, and miscellaneous ancillary spaces for Summit Public Schools: Rainier Charter School, pursuant to their Proposition 39 petition.  Since fiscal year 2013-14, Summit Rainier has been occupying the Mt. Pleasant mini-campus comprised of some of the portable classrooms at the south end of the campus, along with either dedicated or shared use of other permanent facilities.  The fiscal year 2014-15 Facilities Use Agreement included certain improvements to the mini-campus, including removal of 4 buildings, a new restroom building, a shade structure, and fencing reconfiguration.
	 
In order to provide those improvements, the following planning, procurement and construction activities have been completed or are in progress:

As with all construction, the dates are subject to change due to unforeseen conditions.  The construction management firm Strawn Construction, and the contractor Cal State Construction, are working diligently to ensure that school site safety is of paramount importance, and that the learning environment is disrupted as little as possible by the noise, dirt, utility shutdowns, and equipment/vehicular traffic and deliveries associated with construction sites.  The construction manager is in regular contact with Summit Rainier’s Director of Growth on the progression and anticipation of site activities, who has been sharing information and photos with school leaders who are communicating with families.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the report on the Summit Public Schools:  Rainier Charter School Mini Campus Modernization at Mt. Pleasant High School.
